channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How a Festive Night in Seoul Turned Deadly
item.description: There were few police officers around as a mass of revelers swelled. From within the crowd came calls to “push, push” and a big shove, according to witnesses. Then, they began to fall.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, John Yoon, Paul Mozur, Victoria Kim, Lee Su-Hyun and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial on Sunday for the victims of the crowd surge in the Itaewon district of Seoul, the South Korean capital.

item.title: In a country known for crowd control, the scant security for Halloween partygoers raises questions.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Police officers during a rally in October against the government’s labor policy, near the presidential office in Seoul.

item.title: In Clash Over Affirmative Action, Both Sides Invoke Brown v. Board of Education
item.description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Monday about admissions policies at Harvard and the University of North Carolina — and the meaning of a civil rights landmark.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.media:description: The race-conscious admissions policy at Harvard University is at issue in a case before the Supreme Court.

item.title: Did Germany Learn From Its Russia Trouble? The Test May Come in China.
item.description: On the eve of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s first trip to Beijing, concerns are growing that economic dependence on China is leaving his country vulnerable — again.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: As Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany prepares for his first visit to Beijing on Thursday, the country’s intelligence chiefs and allies are warning him against pursuing business as usual with China.

item.title: King Tut Died Long Ago, but the Debate About His Tomb Rages On
item.description: Maybe the walls are disguising the undiscovered burial chamber of Nefertiti. Or “maybe it’s Al Capone’s safe.”
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:description: Tourists looking at the tomb of King Tut, as displayed in a glass case at the Valley of the Kings in Luxor, Egypt, in November 2015.

item.title: Who Is the Man Accused of Attacking Nancy Pelosi’s Husband?
item.description: Those who have known the suspect describe an individual who seemed to fall into isolation and deeply troubling thoughts.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning, Alan Feuer, Charlie Savage and Eliza Fawcett

item.title: Elon Musk, in a Tweet, Shares Link From Site Known to Publish False News
item.description: The tweet on Sunday posted an article that made baseless allegations about the attack on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s husband.
item.dc:creator: Kurtis Lee
item.media:description: In the months since Elon Musk announced he would buy Twitter, questions have been raised about how, or if, he would act to combat misinformation and hate speech on the site.

item.title: Bolsonaro vs. Lula: What to Know About Brazil’s Runoff Election
item.description: The vote comes after a long and ugly campaign that pits two major political figures against each other in race that has tested the country’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voter in the first round of presidential elections this month in São Paulo.

item.title: How the Hasidic Jewish Community Became a Political Force in New York
item.description: Elected officials rarely embrace positions that could antagonize Hasidic leaders, who typically encourage their community to vote as a unified bloc.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:description: On election night, Eric Adams, then the mayor-elect of New York City, shared his victory with Hasidic leaders, including Rabbi Moishe Indig, center.

item.title: Clinton, Obama and DeSantis Lend Star Power to Tight N.Y. Races
item.description: A high-profile display of Republican and Democratic efforts illustrates how many of the state’s races have become unexpectedly close, including the governor’s race.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times, Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul, left, and Representative Lee Zeldin, right, each have about $6 million to spend in the final days of the New York governor’s campaign.

item.title: Gujarat, India: At Least 70 Killed After Bridge Collapses
item.description: The bridge, in the state of Gujarat, was reopened recently after renovation.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Rescuers in India worked at night after a suspension bridge in western Gujarat State collapsed on Sunday.

item.title: Can Hypebeast Magic Revive J. Crew?
item.description: J. Crew was an essential style source until it wasn’t. Back from bankruptcy, the brand has bet on the Supreme honcho Brendon Babenzien to bring streetwear wizardry to the mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay
item.media:credit: Mark Sommerfeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: J. Crew is betting on Brendon Babenzien, here at the clothier’s new store on the Bowery, to deploy his experience at Supreme to drive its revival.

item.title: We Are Very Far From Turning the Page on Trump
item.description: Looking at the midterms as a referendum.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Let’s pretend for a minute that there’s just President Biden to worry about.

item.title: My Teenage Years With the Black Panthers
item.description: A photographer is reunited with images he made as a young man in the turbulent 1960s.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Henson Scales

item.title: The Self-Destruction of Kanye West
item.description: Corporations have finally, rightfully, said “enough” to Kanye West. But what took them so long?
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: The Season of Dark Academia
item.description: The literary genre of “dark academia” may now be less dark than actual academia.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘Why We Take Animal Voyages’
item.description: What I’ve learned from a lifetime of voyaging with animals.
item.dc:creator: Sam Anderson, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Sophia Lanman
item.media:credit: Matthew Pillsbury for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuki, whose name means “snow” in Japanese, at the Philadelphia Zoo.

item.title: Not the Daughter She Wanted
item.description: When it comes to whom she loves, an immigrant daughter can’t make her mother happy. But she holds on to hope, as her mother always taught her to do.

item.title: When You’re Sick at Home
item.description: Your guide to eating well, even when you’re feeling low.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Ben Russell for The New York Times
item.media:description: The smoked brisket pho from Lucy’s Vietnamese in Brooklyn makes for a perfect recovery meal.

item.title: World Cup Dreams, Gone in an Instant
item.description: For hundreds of the world’s best players, injury is the fear shadowing every step, every turn, every tackle as the World Cup looms.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Manchester United defender Raphaël Varane is one of a handful of France players who will, or could, miss the World Cup through an untimely injury.

item.title: New York to Pay $26 Million to Men Wrongly Convicted of Killing Malcolm X
item.description: Muhammad A. Aziz and Khalil Islam spent more than 20 years in prison after the civil rights leader was assassinated in 1965. He had broken with the Nation of Islam.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: Muhammad Aziz walks out of a Manhattan court after his conviction was vacated in New York last November.

item.title: Elon Musk Is Said to Have Ordered Job Cuts Across Twitter
item.description: The billionaire planned to begin layoffs as soon as Saturday, people with knowledge of the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac, Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. Layoffs had been expected and feared by Twitter employees.

item.title: Harlem Mourns the Rev. Calvin Butts III
item.description: Congregants and neighbors remembered a pastor who they said was determined to fight racism and lift up the Black community.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon and Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III’s chair was left empty during a Sunday service dedicated to his memory at Abyssinian Baptist Church. His Bible was placed on the seat and his robe draped over the chair.

item.title: Another Israeli Election Looms, and a Familiar Face Plans a Comeback
item.description: Ousted from the prime minister’s office 16 months ago, Benjamin Netanyahu, the leading candidate, is out to prove his political obituaries were premature.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu in his bulletproof vehicle this month during a campaign stop in Netivot, Israel.

item.title: RSV: What to Know About Symptoms, Transmission and Treatment
item.description: Before the Covid pandemic, most people caught respiratory syncytial virus before the age of 2. Now things have changed.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: How to Stay Sane About Halloween Candy
item.description: No, your children won’t overload on peanut butter cups. Yes, you can eat their mini Snickers.
item.dc:creator: Virginia Sole-Smith

item.title: Covid Symptoms Can Rebound Even If You Don’t Take Paxlovid
item.description: A new study found that more than a third of those who recovered from an infection had symptoms recur days or weeks later.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: Rebound symptoms are common, said one doctor. “It doesn’t mean that things are going south,” he said. “It’s just the natural way the disease goes.”

item.title: How Horror Stories Help Us Cope With Real Life
item.description: Scary movies, books and podcasts can help people think through how they would respond to threats and prepare them for worst-case scenarios, say experts who study the psychology of fear.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Please Let Me Terrify Some Kids on Halloween
item.description: A socially distanced dad hopes that frightening children isn’t a thing of the past.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: An ‘Aggressive Love for Life’ Regardless of Life’s Challenges
item.description: Months after Bradley Carbone met Barbara Torasso, he broke his neck snowboarding. A long recovery brought them closer together.
item.dc:creator: Tammy La Gorce
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bradley Carbone and Barbara Torasso celebrated their union with 300 friends and family at the Boom Boom Room on Sept. 26. “The thread that runs through this relationship is, we do everything as fully as possible,” Mr. Carbone said.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
